reviewText: Please, reviewers, judge the music and the interpretation.  Do not quibble about minor technical defects, that for all we know might be created by your system or even your imagination.  This is a towering performance for the ages and, unlike opera, does not have to be actually watched to be enjoyed.  It's simply awe inspiring, the kind of music that makes one soar into the realms of spirit.  Trancendent, incandescent, humbling.
Title: N/A

reviewText: REVIEW OF GARDINER'S MONTEVERDI VESPERS ON ARCHIV.I hate to say it, but the Emperor is nude.  This may or may not be a great performance (I personally find it, like almost all of Gardiner's work, to be pointless virtuosity, utterly cold).  However, the recording--if one may generously call it that--is egregious.  Such a dark, dull, grainy, smudgy image was unacceptable in 1988 and it's even more unacceptable now.Gardiner and others have released the Monteverdi Vespers on CD, and I would humbly recommend you enjoy it via sound recordings for now.  If you really must have it on video, try the Diego Fasolis version--although not ideal is vastly preferable to this dungeon-like experience.Also one should note, there are NO subtitles although the cover information would seem to indicate otherwise.  (Useful marketing ploy:  false advertising helps sales.)
summary: Sorry, but people have to be warned
Title: N/A

reviewText: ST.MARKS RINGS WITH THE MARVELOUS MUSIC OF MONTEVERDI AS SUNG SENSATIONALLY BY SOLOISTS AND THE MONTEVERDI SINGERS!John Eliot Gardiner, more than other musician today, has been largely responsible for the huge upsurge of interest in Monteverdi's marvelous Vespers of 1610.  As an undergraduate at Cambridge, he formed the Monteverdi Choir for the first performance of this almost unheard of composition.  The Choir today enjoys an international reputation for the performance of a wide range of music.  In all their performances, over the past 25 years, the choir has been accompanied by the English Baroque Soloists, also founded by Gardiner in 1978.This performance, which takes place in the Basilica of San Marco, Venice, includes the following groups in addition to the Choir and Baroque Soloists: His Magesties Sagbutts and Cornetts-London Oratory Junior Choir and vocal solists: Ann Monoyios & Marinella Pennicchi (sopranos); Michael Chance (countertenor); Mark Tucker,Nigel Robson,Sandro Naglia (tenors); Bryn Terfel, Alastair Miles (basses).The origins of the Vespers are not known and it is not known if they were ever performed in Monteverdi's lifetime.  However, Gardiner contends that the work fits perfectly into the architecture and resonance of St. Mark's.  Monteverdi was a theatre composer par excellence as is shown by his operas "L'Orfeo" and "L'incoronazione di Poppea".  Even though much of this performance takes place on a central platform, he also positions singers, at various times, in pulpits, galleries and archways, creating extraordinary visual and acoustic effects.This DVD displays not only the genius of Monteverdi, but the great creativity of Gardiner.  The package also includes  a Bonus section with John Eliot Gardiner talking about the making of the DVD and at the same time showing beautiful scenes of Venice and St. Marks.  This is such an enjoyable listening and visual treat!
summary: A voice teacher and early music fan
Title: N/A

reviewText: My expectations for this DVD were very high given who the musicians are.  Everything pointed to a great purchase, but I will not be playing it again because the video quality is just too poor.  There is also some annoying clicking and the image gets very unreal, almost like something computer generated.  It could have been wonderful, given the illustrious singers, conductor and locale but someone did not take enough care in its production. Too bad!
Title: N/A

reviewText: The performance is one of the best, if not the best, of this wonderful music, and the DVD has the added attraction of being filmed in the beautiful cathedral the music was probably written for.  My copy is perfect, and I see and hear none of the glitches others may have complained about.  What's not to love?  If you love the music and you love great architecture and visual art, you'll love this DVD. It contains an extra feature in which J.E. Gardiner talks about the music and the composer and the wonderful building he conducts it in. GET IT!
Title: N/A

reviewText: An absolute stunner! Crank it up in 5.1 and prepare to transcend. The video transfer's a bit murky, but the shots are well chosen and serve the passages smartly. It's an aural knockout, pure bliss!
